docs.lead_paragraph: HOW AMERICANS YEARN TO EAT HEALTHILY. Particularly as the weather warms and layers of clothing can be shed, and light meals, prepared simply, seem so eminently feasible. And yet, as certainly as the sun sets, so does summer's resolve, leaving many of the lapsed hugging their sweaters, and not because of the breeze. Research organizations like Leo J. Shapiro & Associates in Chicago report that 95 percent of all Americans now say they want to eat low-fat, low-salt, low-cholesterol food, the highest percentage in history. And yet, the percentage of people now suffering from obesity is also at a record high. Is the discrepancy between desire and behavior a result of a national character flaw? Or is it mostly a problem of abundance? According to the World Health Organization, obesity and diet-related maladies increase with a nation's wealth; cultures that adhere most consistently to a low-fat diet are cultures of poverty.
